docs.title: Welcome to ScurryPy
docs.text:
A dataclass-driven Discord API wrapper for Python!

ScurryPy provides the building blocks for working with Discord’s API — clean, modern, and built to be extended. While it serves various squirrel-related shenanigans, it’s perfectly suited for any Discord bot.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Command and event handling
  • Declarative style using decorators
  • Supports both legacy and new features
  • Respects Discord's rate limits
  • Capable of sharding

docs.title: Why ScurryPy?
docs.text:
Philosophy: Minimal, not magical.

  • Minimal — only implement the endpoints you need
  • Explicit over implicit - You control caching, state, and architecture
  • Fork-friendly — easy to extend or customize
  • Fast to adapt — no legacy baggage, clean internals
  • Modern Python — type hints, dataclasses, explicit design
  • Wildcard Routing - Unix shell-style wildcards for components
  • Straight-forward - No avoiding circular imports with from __future__ import annotations

docs.title: Origin Story 🐿️
docs.text:
ScurryPy was created to digitize Squirrel Stash, a physical card game about competitive squirrels hoarding acorns. Existing Discord libraries are too opinionated for the custom game logic needed, so ScurryPy emerged as a minimal wrapper that stays out of your way.

The result: a library that's perfect for games, experiments, and any bot where you need architectural control.

docs.title: Advanced Examples
docs.text:
The following examples should work out-of-the-box and assume you have your bot set up.

For setup, see the Bot setup guide.

Looking for examples about older features? Check out Legacy Examples

About these examples

Each example is self-contained and can be copied directly into your bot between setup and client.run().

Beware of similar command names!

docs.title: Adding Persistent Data
docs.text:
Demonstrates how to inject user-defined data to run alongside your bot. This example uses a PG database connection. 

from dataclasses import dataclass
import asyncpg

@dataclass
class MyState(scurrypy.BaseConfig):
    pg_conn: asyncpg.Pool = None  # pool of connections

@client.setup_hook
async def init_db(bot: scurrypy.Client):
    bot.config.pg_conn = await asyncpg.create_pool(
        host="your-host",
        user="your-username",
        database="your-db-name"
    )
    print("DB pool initialized")

@client.shutdown_hook
async def close_db(bot: scurrypy.Client):
    await bot.config.pg_conn.close()
    print("DB pool closed")

Note on .config type

While .config can technically be anything, it is recommended to use scurrypy.BaseConfig and the dataclass decorator.

Dataclasses make accessing fields more object-like instead of dict-like.

docs.title: Requesting a Resource
docs.text:
Resources (like a channel or a message) can be requested for through client.

Demonstrates requesting a message to attach a thread. 

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', 'Demonstrates creating a thread from a message!'), 
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    resp = await event.interaction.respond('You got it!', with_response=True)
    await bot.fetch_channel(event.interaction.channel_id).create_thread_from_message(resp.interaction.response_message_id, 'Thread name')

docs.title: Requesting Bot Emojis
docs.text:
Requesting bot emojis is like fetching any other resource except it's part of the client.

Demonstrates requesting bot emojis. 

@client.setup_hook
async def fetch_bot_emojis(bot: scurrypy.Client):
    await bot.emojis.fetch_all()

Tip

This is passed to the user so that the client only loads what is needed.

docs.title: Minimal Slash Command
docs.text:
Demonstrates responding to a slash command. 

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', 'Demonstrate the minimal slash command!'),
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    await event.interaction.respond(f'Greetings from ScurryPy!')

Guild vs Global

  • Use global commands for production bots (may take up to 1 hour to appear).
  • Use guild commands for instant registration within a guild.

docs.title: Building with Discord's V2 Components
docs.text:
Demonstrates building the V2 component: a container. 

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', "Demonstrate using Discord's new component system!"),
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    await event.interaction.respond(
        scurrypy.MessagePart(
            components=[
                scurrypy.ContainerPart(
                    accent_color=int('d4af37', 16),
                    components=[
                        scurrypy.TextDisplay("It's dangerous to go alone!"),
                        scurrypy.Separator(),
                        scurrypy.TextDisplay("Take this.")
                    ]
                )
            ],
            flags=scurrypy.MessageFlags.IS_COMPONENTS_V2
        )
    )

docs.title: Building and Responding to Components
docs.text:
Demonstrates building a button and responding to a user pressing it.

import random

def create_row(event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    """Functionalize button creation."""

    emoji = '❤️' if event.interaction.type == scurrypy.InteractionTypes.APPLICATION_COMMAND else '❤️‍🔥'

    return scurrypy.ActionRowPart(
        components=[
            scurrypy.Button(
                style=scurrypy.ButtonStyles.PRIMARY, 
                custom_id='best_custom_id', 
                label='Press me!', 
                emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel(name=emoji)
            )
        ]
    )

@client.component('best_custom_id')
async def route(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    adj = random.choice(['wonderous', 'beautiful', 'charming', 'vibrant', 'sinister'])

    row = create_row(event)

    await event.interaction.update(
        scurrypy.MessagePart(
            content=f'Hello *{adj.capitalize()}* world!',
            components=[row]
        )
    )

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', 'Demonstrate using components!'), 
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    adj = random.choice(['wonderous', 'beautiful', 'charming', 'vibrant', 'sinister'])

    row = create_row(event)

    await event.interaction.respond(
        scurrypy.MessagePart(
            content=f'Hello *{adj.capitalize()}* world!',
            components=[row]
        )
    )

docs.title: Building and Responding to Select Components
docs.text:
Demonstrates building a string select component and responding. 

@client.component('on_string_select')
async def on_string_select(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    await event.interaction.respond(f'You selected option: **{event.data.values[0]}**!')

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', 'Demonstrate the select components!'), 
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    options = [
        scurrypy.SelectOption(
            label='Caterpillar',
            emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel('🐛'),
            value='Caterpillar',
            description='(best option)'
        ),
        scurrypy.SelectOption(
            label='Butterfly',
            emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel('🦋'),
            value='Butterfly'
        ),
        scurrypy.SelectOption(
            label='Ant',
            emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel('🐜'),
            value='Ant'
        )
    ]

    row = scurrypy.ActionRowPart(
        [
            scurrypy.StringSelect(
                custom_id='on_string_select',
                placeholder='Choose an option...',
                options=options
            )
        ]
    )

    await event.interaction.respond(
        scurrypy.MessagePart(
            content='Select an option:',
            components=[row]
        )
    )

docs.title: Building and responding to a Modal
docs.text:
Demonstrates using the modal feature and extracting the user's responses. 

@client.component('modal_one')
async def modal_one(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    label = event.data.get_modal_data('bug_select')[0]
    details = event.data.get_modal_data('bug_explanation')

    await event.interaction.respond(
        f"Form Data: \nSelect: {label} \nDetails: {details}",
        ephemeral=True
    )

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', 'Demonstrate the modal request/response!'),
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    select_options = [
        scurrypy.SelectOption(
            label='Caterpillar',
            emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel('🐛'),
            value='Caterpillar',
            description='(best option)'
        ),
        scurrypy.SelectOption(
            label='Butterfly',
            emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel('🦋'),
            value='Butterfly'
        ),
        scurrypy.SelectOption(
            label='Ant',
            emoji=scurrypy.EmojiModel('🐜'),
            value='Ant'
        )
    ]

    select_label = scurrypy.Label(
        label="What's your favorite bug?",
        component=scurrypy.StringSelect(
            custom_id='bug_select',
            options=select_options,
            placeholder='Choose...',
            required=True
        )
    )

    input_label = scurrypy.Label(
        label='Why is it your favorite?',
        description='Provide as much detail as possible!',
        component=scurrypy.TextInput(
            custom_id='bug_explanation',
            placeholder='Write your explanation here...',
            style=scurrypy.TextInputStyles.PARAGRAPH,
            min_length=25,
            max_length=250
        )
    )

    await event.interaction.respond_modal(
        scurrypy.ModalPart(
            title='Bug Report',
            custom_id='modal_one',
            components=[select_label, input_label]
        )
    )

docs.title: Responding to an Event
docs.text:
Demonstrates responding to a reaction added to one of the bot's messages.

Important

Make sure to toggle the GUILD_MESSAGE_REACTIONS intent!

@client.event("MESSAGE_REACTION_ADD")
async def on_reaction_add(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.ReactionAddEvent):
    if event.message_author_id == bot.application_id:
        await bot.fetch_message(event.channel_id, event.message_id).send('Love ya too!')

docs.title: Adding Attachments
docs.text:
Demonstrates adding multiple attachments to a legacy embed. This example can be extended to Containers and other fields that need an https or attachment scheme. 

from datetime import datetime, timezone

def set_user_author(user: scurrypy.UserModel):
    """Set the embed author to the user invoking the command."""

    return scurrypy.EmbedAuthor(
        user.username,
        f"https://cdn.discordapp.com/avatars/{user.id}/{user.avatar}.png"
    )

def set_timestamp():
    """Format time per Discord's docs."""
    return datetime.now(timezone.utc).isoformat()

@client.command(
    scurrypy.SlashCommand('example', 'Demonstrate adding an attachment!'), 
    GUILD_ID # must be guild ID your bot is in!
)
async def on_example(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
    await event.interaction.respond(
        scurrypy.MessagePart(
            attachments=[
                scurrypy.Attachment("relative/path/to/file.png", 'my description.'),
                scurrypy.Attachment("relative/path/to/animation.gif", 'amazing animation!')
            ],
            embeds=[
                scurrypy.EmbedPart(
                    title='Example Embed',
                    author=set_user_author(event.interaction.member.user),
                    color=int('d4af37', 16),
                    thumbnail=scurrypy.EmbedThumbnail('attachment://file.png'),
                    image=scurrypy.EmbedImage('attachment://animation.gif'),
                    timestamp=set_timestamp()
                )
            ]
        )
    )

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This section details getting started with ScurryPy including installation and code snippets.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To install the ScurryPy package, run: 

pip install scurrypy

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
Place the following code in your main file: 

import scurrypy, os
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv(dotenv_path='./path/to/env') # omit argument if your env file is on the same level

client = scurrypy.Client(
    token=os.getenv("DISCORD_TOKEN"),
    application_id=APPLICATION_ID  # your bot's application ID
)

# your code or example snippets here

client.run()

Place the following variables in your .env file: 

DISCORD_TOKEN="your-bot-token"

Setup rules

  • Keep sensitive values (like your bot's token) in a .env file instead of hardcoding them.
  • Always place client.run() at the end of your script, after all commands and event handlers are registered.

docs.title: Setting and Responding to a Command Prefix
docs.text:
Demonstrates responding to a message prefix command. Sends the message Pong! if !ping is sent.

Important

Using message prefix commands requires the PRIVILEGED intent MESSAGE_CONTENT!

@client.prefix_command("ping")
async def on_span(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.MessageCreateEvent):
    await event.message.send("Pong!")

docs.title: Building an Embed
docs.text:
Demonstrate building an embed in response to a message prefix. 

from datetime import datetime, timezone

def set_timestamp():
    """Format time per Discord's docs."""
    return datetime.now(timezone.utc).isoformat()

def set_user_author(user: scurrypy.UserModel):
    """Set the embed author to the user invoking the command."""

    return scurrypy.EmbedAuthor(
        name=user.username,
        icon_url=f"https://cdn.discordapp.com/avatars/{user.id}/{user.avatar}.png"
    )

@client.prefix_command("embed")
async def on_embed(bot: scurrypy.Client, event: scurrypy.MessageCreateEvent):
    await event.message.send(
        scurrypy.MessagePart(
            embeds=[
                scurrypy.EmbedPart(
                    title='Example Embed',
                    author=set_user_author(event.message.author),
                    color=int('d4af37', 16),
                    timestamp=set_timestamp()
                )
            ]
        )
    )

Tip

While this example shows building an embed in response to a message prefix, embeds can also be built in response to InteractionEvent!

docs.title: Migrations
docs.text: Discord updates its features frequently, which can affect how legacy code works. This migration guide helps you transition from older examples to their updated equivalents, with a brief explanation of the changes and how to use them in the new API.

docs.title: Prefix to Application Command
docs.text:
Application commands are a newer, feature-rich, and less cumbersome replacement for message prefix commands. There are three types:

  • Slash commands (e.g., /example)
  • Message commands (message option under Apps)
  • User commands (user option under Apps)

Why is this less cumbersome? You no longer need to listen to and parse message content (which is now a privileged intent). Instead, you just listen for InteractionCreate events — and that’s where ScurryPy comes in!

Old vs New

  • Prefix command example
  • Slash command example

docs.title: Embed to Container
docs.text:
Containers display and format much like traditional embeds, but with added flexibility for arranging components and customizing message layout.

Some new features of containers introduces:

  • Media Gallery
  • Section
  • Separators
  • and more!

Check out Containers for more!

Old vs New

  • Embed example
  • Container example

docs.title: Welcome to the API section!
docs.text:
This section covers the high-level objects. It provides entry-level classes for building a bot such as the client, registering commands and event listeners, and accessing Discord resources.

  • Client - main entry point for discord bot.
  • Intents - specify what events you want your bot to receive.
  • Commands - register and runs commands and event handlers.
  • UI Components - tools for building Discord's new component setup.
  • Components - register and runs component handlers.
  • Message - tools for building a message.
  • Models - dataclasses mimicing Discord's payload structure for dot access.
  • Role - layout for building a role.
  • Embed (Legacy) - tools for adding embedded content within a message.

docs.title: Client API
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.client module.

docs.title: Client
docs.text:
Bases: ClientLike

Main entry point for Discord bots. Ties together the moving parts: gateway, HTTP, event dispatching, command handling, and resource managers.

Parameters:

  • token (str) –

    the bot's token

  • application_id (int) –

    the bot's user ID

  • intents (int, default: DEFAULT ) –

    gateway intents. Defaults to Intents.DEFAULT.

  • config (BaseConfig, default: None ) –

    user-defined config data

  • sync_commands (bool, default: True ) –

    toggle registering commands. Defaults to True.

  • debug_mode (bool, default: False ) –

    toggle debug messages. Defaults to False.

  • prefix (str, default: None ) –

    set message prefix if using command prefixes

  • quiet (bool, default: False ) –

    if INFO, DEBUG, and WARN should be logged

docs.title: prefix_command
docs.text:
Decorator registers prefix commands by the name of the function.

Parameters:

  • name (str) –

    name of the command

    Important

    Prefix commands are CASE-INSENSITIVE.

docs.title: component
docs.text:
Decorator registers a function for a component handler.

Parameters:

  • custom_id (str) –

    Identifier of the component. Must match the custom_id set where the component was created.

docs.title: command
docs.text:
Decorator registers a function to a command handler.

Parameters:

  • command (SlashCommand | MessageCommand | UserCommand) –

    the command object

  • guild_ids (list[int], default: None ) –

    Guild IDs to register command to (if any). If omitted, the command is global.

docs.title: event
docs.text:
Decorator registers a function for an event handler.

Parameters:

  • event_name (str) –

    event name (must be a valid event)

docs.title: setup_hook
docs.text:
Decorator registers a setup hook. (Runs once before the bot starts listening)

Parameters:

  • func (callable) –

    callback to the setup function

docs.title: shutdown_hook
docs.text:
Decorator registers a shutdown hook. (Runs once before the bot exits the loop)

Parameters:

  • func (callable) –

    callback to the shutdown function

docs.title: Intents
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.intents module.

Important

For unverified bots, privileged intents can only be used if your bot is in less than 100 guilds! Otherwise, your bot needs to be verified to use these intents.

docs.title: Intents
docs.text:
Gateway intent flags (bitwise). For an exhaustive list what intents let your bot listen to what events, see list of intents.

Note

Not all intents are listed. Intents not listed are not yet supported.

docs.title: GUILDS = 1 << 0 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events related to guilds.

docs.title: GUILD_MEMBERS = 1 << 1 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text:
Privileged Intent

Requires the app setting Server Members Intent to be toggled.

Receive events related to guild members.

docs.title: GUILD_EMOJIS_AND_STICKERS = 1 << 3 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events related to custom emojis and stickers.

docs.title: GUILD_INTEGRATIONS = 1 << 4 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events related to integrations within a guild.

docs.title: GUILD_WEBHOOKS = 1 << 5 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Track webhook events within a guild.

docs.title: GUILD_MESSAGES = 1 << 9 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events about messages within a guild.

docs.title: GUILD_MESSAGE_REACTIONS = 1 << 10 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Track changes in reactions on messages.

docs.title: MESSAGE_CONTENT = 1 << 15 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text:
Privileged Intent

Requires the app setting Message Content Intent to be toggled.

Access content of messages.

docs.title: set_intents
docs.text:
Set bot intents. See Intents Intents.DEFAULT = (GUILDS | GUILD_MESSAGES) will also be set.

Parameters:

  • **flags (Unpack[IntentFlagParams], default: {} ) –

    intents to set

Raises:

  • ValueError –

    invalid flag

Returns:

  • int –

    combined intents field

docs.title: IntentFlagParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Gateway intent selection parameters.

docs.title: Welcome to the Events section!
docs.text:
This section is dedicated to the modeling of Discord's event payloads. Events are sent back when an event your bot is listening for is triggered (see Gateway Intents for more). These classes themselves have no methods and are used purely for reference.

  • Interaction - events related to interactions.
  • Message - events related to messages.
  • Channel - events related to channels.
  • Guild - events related to guilds.
  • Reaction - events related to reactions.
  • Ready - the READY event sent when the bot goes online.

docs.title: Welcome to the Internals section!
docs.text:
Internal API

These classes are for internal use only.

Users should interact with Client and other public API classes instead.

This warning will be at the top of every page.

docs.title: Lost? Head back to the Landing Page, silly!
docs.text:
This section is dedicated to internal classes and structures. These classes work underneath the public interface and are not meant to be touched by the average user.

Any breaks that occur from attempting to use the internals as a way of overriding default behavior is not a fault of this library!

Proceed at your own risk!

  • Data Model - parent class for hydrating child dataclasses with Discord's response payloads.
  • HTTP - HTTP client session tools for managing HTTP requests with Discord with built-in rate limiting.
  • Dispatchers - registers and responds to Discord events.
  • Gateway - websocket tools for managing a websocket connection with Discord.
  • Logger - logging tools for logging events.
  • Discord Error - models Discord's API error structure and outputs a more readable message.

docs.title: Welcome to the Resources section!
docs.text:
This section is dedicated to modeling Discord's resources. These resources represent an object with methods to interact with itself. Resources need to be requested unless the resource is part of the event object. Resources act as a thin layer over the HTTP client handling requests internally. See Events for event-related details.

  • Interaction - the interaction resource. This is where you respond to interactions.
  • Message - the message resource. This is where you can create, edit, and delete a message.
  • User - the user resource. This is where you can fetch information about a user or guild member.
  • Channel - the channel resource. This is where you can create, edit, and delete a channel.
  • Guild - the guild resource. This is where you can fetch information about a guild.
  • Bot Emojis - data pertaining to bot-owned emojis. Treated like a resource.
  • Application - the application resource. This is where you can fetch information about an application.

Bases: TypedDict

Params when fetching guild channel messages.

docs.title: limit: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Max number of messages to return. Range 1 - 100. Default 50.

docs.title: before: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get messages before this message ID.

docs.title: after: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get messages after this message ID.

docs.title: around: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get messages around this message ID.

docs.title: ThreadFromMessageParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Params when attaching a thread to a message.

docs.title: rate_limit_per_user: int instance-attribute
docs.text: time (seconds) user waits before sending another message.

docs.title: Guild Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.guild module.

docs.title: Guild dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: DataModel

Represents a Discord guild.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the guild.

docs.title: name: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Name of the guild.

docs.title: icon: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Image hash of the guild's icon.

docs.title: splash: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Image hash of the guild's splash.

docs.title: owner: Optional[bool] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: If the member is the owner. (Get Current User Guilds)

docs.title: owner_id: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: OD of the owner of the guild.

docs.title: roles: list[int] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: List of IDs registered in the guild.

docs.title: emojis: list[EmojiModel] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: List of emojis registered in the guild.

docs.title: mfa_level: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Required MFA level of the guild.

docs.title: application_id: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the application if the guild is created by a bot.

docs.title: system_channel_id: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Channel ID where system messages go (e.g., welcome messages, boost events).

docs.title: system_channel_flags: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: System channel flags.

docs.title: rules_channel_id: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Channel ID where rules are posted.

docs.title: max_members: Optional[int] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Maximum member capacity for the guild.

docs.title: description: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Description of the guild.

docs.title: banner: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Image hash of the guild's banner.

docs.title: preferred_locale: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Preferred locale of the guild.

docs.title: public_updates_channel_id: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Channel ID of announcement or public updates.

docs.title: approximate_member_count: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Approximate number of members in the guild.

docs.title: nsfw_level: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: NSFW level of the guild.

docs.title: safety_alerts_channel_id: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Channel ID for safety alerts.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetch the Guild object by the given ID.

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[FetchGuildParams], default: {} ) –

    guild fetch params

    Note

    If no kwargs are provided, default to with_counts = False

Returns:

  • Guild –

    the Guild object

docs.title: fetch_channels async
docs.text:
Fetch this guild's channels.

Returns:

  • list[Channel] –

    list of the guild's channels

docs.title: create_channel async
docs.text:
Create a channel in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_CHANNELS → required to create a channel

Parameters:

  • channel (GuildChannel) –

    the buildable guild channel

Returns:

  • Channel –

    the created channel

docs.title: fetch_guild_member async
docs.text:
Fetch a member in this guild.

Important

Requires the GUILD_MEMBERS privileged intent!

Parameters:

  • user_id (int) –

    user ID of the member to fetch

Returns:

  • MemberModel –

    member's data

docs.title: fetch_guild_members async
docs.text:
Fetch guild members in this guild.

Important

Requires the GUILD_MEMBERS privileged intent!

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[FetchGuildMembersParams], default: {} ) –

    guild members fetch params

    Note

    If no kwargs are provided, default to 1 guild member limit.

Returns:

  • list[MemberModel] –

    list of member data

docs.title: add_guild_member_role async
docs.text:
Append a role to a guild member of this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to add a role to the user

Parameters:

  • user_id (int) –

    ID of the member for the role

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of the role to append

docs.title: remove_guild_member_role async
docs.text:
Remove a role from a guild member of this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to remove a role from the user

Parameters:

  • user_id (int) –

    ID of the member with the role

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of the role to remove

docs.title: fetch_guild_role async
docs.text:
Fetch a role in this guild.

Parameters:

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of the role to fetch

Returns:

  • RoleModel –

    fetched role's data

docs.title: fetch_guild_roles async
docs.text:
Fetch all roles in this guild.

Returns:

  • list[RoleModel] –

    list of fetched roles' data

docs.title: create_guild_role async
docs.text:
Create a role in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to add a role to the guild

Parameters:

  • role (Role) –

    role to create

Returns:

  • RoleModel –

    new role data

docs.title: modify_guild_role async
docs.text:
Modify a role in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to modify a role in the guild

Parameters:

  • role (Role) –

    role with changes

Returns:

  • RoleModel –

    role with changes

docs.title: delete_guild_role async
docs.text:
Delete a role in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to delete a role in the guild

Parameters:

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of role to delete

docs.title: Interaction Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.interaction module.

docs.title: Interaction dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: DataModel

Represents a Discord Interaction object.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the interaction.

docs.title: token: str instance-attribute
docs.text: Continuation token for responding to the interaction.

docs.title: type: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Type of interaction. See InteractionTypes.

docs.title: channel_id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the channel where the interaction was sent.

docs.title: application_id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the application that owns the interaction.

docs.title: app_permissions: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Bitwise set of permissions pertaining to the location of the interaction.

docs.title: member: MemberModel = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Guild member invoking the interaction.

docs.title: locale: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Invoking user's locale.

docs.title: guild_locale: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Locale of the guild the interaction was invoked (if invoked in a guild).

docs.title: guild_id: Optional[int] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of guild the interaction was invoked (if invoked in a guild).

docs.title: guild: Optional[GuildModel] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Partial guild object of the guild the interaction was invoked (if invoked in a guild).

docs.title: channel: Optional[Channel] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Partial channel object the interaction was invoked.

docs.title: respond async
docs.text:
Create a message in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    content as a string or from MessagePart

  • with_response (bool, default: False ) –

    if the interaction data should be returned. Defaults to False.

  • **flags (Unpack[MessageFlagParams], default: {} ) –

    message flags to set. (set respective flag to True to toggle.)

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid message type

docs.title: update async
docs.text:
Update a message in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    content as a string or from MessagePart

  • **flags (Unpack[MessageFlagParams], default: {} ) –

    message flags to set

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid message type

docs.title: respond_modal async
docs.text:
Create a modal in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • modal (ModalPart) –

    modal data

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid modal type

docs.title: InteractionDataTypes
docs.text: Interaction data types constants.

docs.title: SLASH_COMMAND = 1 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: The interaction is a slash command.

docs.title: USER_COMMAND = 2 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: The interaction is attached to a user.

docs.title: MESSAGE_COMMAND = 3 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: The interaction is attached to a message.

docs.title: InteractionCallbackTypes
docs.text: Interaction callback types constants.

docs.title: PONG = 1 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Acknowledge a Ping.

docs.title: CHANNEL_MESSAGE_WITH_SOURCE = 4 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Respond to an interaction with a message.

docs.title: DEFERRED_CHANNEL_MESSAGE_WITH_SOURCE = 5 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Acknowledge an interaction and edit a response later. User sees a loading state.

docs.title: DEFERRED_UPDATE_MESSAGE = 6 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Acknowledge an interaction and edit the original message later. The user does NOT see a loading state. (Components only)

docs.title: UPDATE_MESSAGE = 7 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Edit the message in which the component was attached.

docs.title: APPLICATION_COMMAND_AUTOCOMPLETE_RESULT = 8 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Respond to an autocomplete interaction with suggested choices.

docs.title: MODAL = 9 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Respond to an interaction with a popup modal (not available for MODAL_SUBMIT and PING interactions).

docs.title: LAUNCH_ACTIVITY = 12 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Launch an activity associated with the app (Activities must be enabled).

docs.title: Message Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.message module.

docs.title: Message dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: DataModel

A Discord message.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the message

docs.title: channel_id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Channel ID of the message.

docs.title: author: UserModel = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: User data of author of the message.

docs.title: content: str = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Content of the message.

docs.title: pinned: bool = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: If the message is pinned.

docs.title: type: int = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Type of message.

docs.title: webhook_id: Optional[int] = None class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the webhook if the message is a webhook.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetches the message data based on the given channel ID and message id.

Returns:

  • Message –

    the message object

docs.title: send async
docs.text:
Sends a new message to the current channel.

Permissions
  • SEND_MESSAGES → required to senf your own messages

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    can be just text or the MessagePart for dynamic messages

Returns:

  • Message –

    the new Message object with all fields populated

docs.title: edit async
docs.text:
Edits this message.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → ONLY if editing another user's message

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    can be just text or the MessagePart for dynamic messages

docs.title: reply async
docs.text:
Reply to this message with a new message.

Permissions
  • SEND_MESSAGES → required to send the message

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    the new message

docs.title: crosspost async
docs.text:
Crosspost this message in an Annoucement channel to all following channels.

Permissions
  • SEND_MESSAGES → required to publish your own messages
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → required to publish messages from others

Returns:

  • Message –

    the published (crossposted) message

docs.title: delete async
docs.text: Deletes this message.

docs.title: add_reaction async
docs.text:
Add a reaction from this message.

Permissions
  • READ_MESSAGE_HISTORY → required to view message
  • ADD_REACTIONS → required to create reaction

Parameters:

  • emoji (EmojiModel | str) –

    the standard emoji (str) or custom emoji (EmojiModel)

docs.title: remove_reaction async
docs.text:
Remove the bot's reaction from this message.

Parameters:

  • emoji (EmojiModel | str) –

    the standard emoji (str) or custom emoji (EmojiModel)

docs.title: remove_user_reaction async
docs.text:
Remove a specific user's reaction from this message.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → required to remove another user's reaction

Parameters:

  • emoji (EmojiModel | str) –

    the standard emoji (str) or custom emoji (EmojiModel)

  • user_id (int) –

    user's ID

docs.title: remove_all_reactions async
docs.text:
Clear all reactions from this message.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → required to remove all reaction

docs.title: pin async
docs.text: Pin this message to its channel's pins.

docs.title: unpin async
docs.text: Unpin this message from its channel's pins.
